Executive Summary:



(a) The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy: 

Global operates the Global Erie Blvd Terminal in a manner that prevents significant incidents or substantial threats of incidents through adherence to legal requirements, management systems, procedures and personnel training.  Global understands the shared value of safety and environmental protection for our employees, the public and the communities we serve as a vital component of our energy infrastructure.



(b) The Stationary Source and Substance Handled: 

The Global Erie Blvd Terminal is owned by the Canadian Pacific Railway and operated by Global Companies LLC (Global), headquartered in Waltham, Massachusetts.  At this terminal, railcars and tank trucks of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) are off-loaded into storage tanks within an earthen  mounded tank farm.  LPG is then loaded into tank trucks for off-site delivery. Propane and butane are the Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) regulated chemicals stored at the terminal which exceed a threshold quantity.



(c) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:  

The Global Erie Boulevard Terminal (terminal) is a secured facility and manned during normal business hours.  The terminal is regulated as a Program Level 3, CAP facility.  General accidental release prevention programs and LPG-specific release prevention steps incorporated for the covered process include the following:



--The terminal is a fully fenced facility, with remote activated gates to limit entry to authorized personnel only

--Operating procedures have been developed and implemented for operations performed by terminal operators

--The Terminal Manager and Terminal Operators are provided with initial and refresher training in accordance with the National Propane Gas Association Certified Employee Training Program (CETP)

-- The Terminal Manager and Terminal Operators are trained to the emergency response operation

s level, per OSHA's Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) regulations contained in 29 CFR 1910.120

--Railcar inspections are conducted per an established schedule and in compliance with United States Department of Transportation (DOT) regulations

--Global conducts, or arranges for, process equipment inspections, testing, and maintenance on established intervals

--Safety information has been developed for the covered process chemicals, technology of the process, and process equipment

--The terminal conducts routine hazard reviews, inclusive of a Fire Safety Analysis (FSA) and/or a hazard analysis checklist



(d) Five Year Accident History:  

There have been no accidental releases meeting the definition contained in 40 CFR ?68.42(a) within the last five years of operation, or in the history of the plant.



(e) The Emergency Response Program: 

The facility has developed an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP), which has been coordinated with local emergency response groups, including the Albany Fire Department.  Terminal Operators are trained to the HAZWOPER Operations level, inclusive of required refresher training. They receive training on the ERAP and participate in an emergency response drill on an annual basis.



Global has also contracted with a private hazardous material response contractor who is available 24-hours per day on an on-call basis.  Global is responsible for coordinating the notifications required to initiate an emergency response. The ERAP provides the essential planning for effectively protecting the public and the environment during emergency situations.



(f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety: 

The Global Erie Boulevard Terminal completed its most recent Compliance Audit and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in the second quarter of 2019. As a result of the audit and PHA, a number of improvements to the risk management program have either been completed or are planned.  The improvements are intended to improve the

safety of the process and minimize the potential for a release.  Changes primarily include program changes (improved documentation), operating procedure or checklist updates, and employee training.



Registration:

This Risk Management Plan includes the required registration information referenced in 40 CFR ?68.160(b)(1) through (22) to be reported for a Program 3 process.



Offsite Consequence Analysis:

As a Program 3 covered process with a regulated flammable substance, an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) has been performed for one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario.  The required data from the OCA is contained within this Risk Management Plan.



Five Year Accident History:

There have been no accidental releases meeting the definition contained in 40 CFR ?68.42(a) within the last five years of operation, or in the history of the plant.
